comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -146,9 +119,16 @@ def __init__(self, alg_name, secret_key = None):
             'length_secret_key' : int(self._kem.contents.length_secret_key),
             'length_ciphertext' : int(self._kem.contents.length_ciphertext),
             'length_shared_secret' : int(self._kem.contents.length_shared_secret) }
+
         if secret_key:
             self.secret_key = ct.create_string_buffer(secret_key, self._kem.contents.length_secret_key)
 
+    def __enter__(self):
+        return self
+
+    def __exit__(self, ctx_type, ctx_value, ctx_traceback):
+        self.free()
+
     def generate_keypair(self):
comment.body: Rename generate\_keypair to keypair. Similarly for encaps and decaps.

pull_request.title: Refactor liboqs-python classes / API changes
pull_request.body:
As per the weekly meeting, here is a PR for discussion of the code changes pushed yesterday.

The tasks & discussion points include:
* Update Py method names to match C KEM & Sig structs
* Douglas: does the OQS_[KEM|SIG] represent an instance of an alg, or a general mechanism?
* Douglas: methods, secret_key as member vs method arg
* Douglas: include length checks in some of the functions
* Douglas: do KAT tests somewhere?
* Wrapper doesn't support nist-branch Sig interface at present

repo.name: liboqs-python
repo.description: [work in progress] Python 3 bindings for liboqs

repo.name: liboqs-python
repo.description: [work in progress] Python 3 bindings for liboqs

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -193,12 +173,49 @@ def free(self):
     def __repr__(self):
         return "Key encapsulation mechanism: " + self._kem.contents.method_name.decode()
 
+
+liboqs.OQS_KEM_new.restype = ct.POINTER(OQS_KEM)
+liboqs.OQS_KEM_alg_identifier.restype = ct.c_char_p
+
+
+def is_KEM_enabled(alg_name):
+    """Returns True if the KEM algorithm is enabled, False otherwise.
+
+    Attribute:
+        alg_name -- a KEM mechanism algorithm name
+    """
+    try:
+        kem = liboqs.OQS_KEM_new(ct.create_string_buffer(alg_name.encode()))
+        if(kem.contents):
+            liboqs.OQS_KEM_free(kem)
+            return True
+    except ValueError:
+        pass
+    return False
+
+
+_KEM_alg_ids = [liboqs.OQS_KEM_alg_identifier(i) for i in range(liboqs.OQS_KEM_alg_count())]
+_supported_KEMs = [i.decode() for i in _KEM_alg_ids]
+_enabled_KEMs = [i for i in _supported_KEMs if is_KEM_enabled(i)]
+
+
+def get_enabled_KEM_mechanisms():
+    """Returns the list of enabled KEM mechanisms."""
+    return _enabled_KEMs
+
+def print_enabled_KEM_mechanisms():
comment.body: Do we need to have print\_enabled\_KEM\_mechanisms? Doesn't seem like a "fundamental" method in the class.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,5 +1,5 @@
-from oqs.wrapper import _enabled_KEMs, _supported_KEMs, KeyEncapsulation
-from oqs.wrapper import _enabled_sigs, _supported_sigs, Signature
+from oqs.wrapper import _enabled_KEMs, _supported_KEMs, OQS_KEM
comment.body: Why are `_enabled_KEMs`, `_supported_KEMs`, `_enabled_sigs`, `_supported_sigs` available as top level objects?  Can we just have them as static methods on OQS\_KEM / OQS\_SIG?

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -146,9 +119,16 @@ def __init__(self, alg_name, secret_key = None):
             'length_secret_key' : int(self._kem.contents.length_secret_key),
             'length_ciphertext' : int(self._kem.contents.length_ciphertext),
             'length_shared_secret' : int(self._kem.contents.length_shared_secret) }
+
         if secret_key:
             self.secret_key = ct.create_string_buffer(secret_key, self._kem.contents.length_secret_key)
 
+    def __enter__(self):
+        return self
+
+    def __exit__(self, ctx_type, ctx_value, ctx_traceback):
+        self.free()
+
     def generate_keypair(self):
comment.body: The keypair/encaps/decaps functions are very unclear. The OQS C API stays close to the NIST API, sure, but I believe the higher-level languages should aim to be clearer. Python programmers shouldn't have to be familiar with the NIST names. Keypair by itself is cryptic; is it to obtain the key, set it, generate it?

     def __repr__(self):
         return "Key encapsulation mechanism: " + self._kem.contents.method_name.decode()
 
+
+liboqs.OQS_KEM_new.restype = ct.POINTER(OQS_KEM)

+
+def is_KEM_enabled(alg_name):

comment.body: I want to replace this with "pprint()", the built in pretty printer. If there's a need to encapsulate the enabled kem/sigs in another data structure, magic internal methods can be overridden to print what is needed.
